Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is concerned with geometric and analytic approaches to the study of solutions of Diophantine equations, one of the oldest branches of mathematics. The study of Diophantine equations involves finding whole number solutions to polynomial equalities, a remarkably difficult problem -- it is not possible to devise a process with a finite number of operations that can decide whether a general Diophantine equation has a solution. This area of mathematics is finding applications in a range of fields in theoretical and practical computer science, from encryption protocols to error correcting and data management. It is also driving the development of sophisticated algorithms to test numerically some of the theoretical predictions. This project aims to deepen and extend knowledge in this important subject.

Specifically, the project is concerned with cohomological obstructions to the existence of rational and integral points on algebraic surfaces, investigations of arithmetic implications of derived equivalence for K3 surfaces, geometric and analytic approaches to asymptotics of rational points of bounded height on higher-dimensional varieties, and with the study of variation of arithmetic properties in families of varieties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main focus of this proposal was a fundamental attribute of higher-dimensional geometric shapes, called algebraic varieties. These are given by systems of polynomial equations in many variables, and their theory can be viewed as a highly-developed nonlinear algebra. While linear algebra is adequate for the description of local properties of the world around us, nonlinear algebra is more appropriate for the description of global properties. 


The notion in question is rationality. An algebraic variety is called rational if, after a polynomial change of variables, it is the reference variety, the basic projective space. Finding such polynomial transformations explicitly is very difficult. Instead, a large body of the mathematical literature is concerned with definitions and computations of obstructions to rationality. The case of dimension 2 was a major research area about 100 years ago. In dimension 3, and higher, after big advances around 1970, there was essentially no progress, until recently. The situation changed dramatically several years ago, with the introduction of new specialization techniques. The PI, in joint work with Hassett, Kresch, and Pirutka, settled the stable rationality problem in dimension 3, with the exception of cubic threefolds, and produced examples showing that rationality behavior can change in families of algebraic varieties. In joint work with Kontsevich, he discovered a fundamental new invariant, the Burnside group, proved a specialization result in this context, and established a surprising connection between equivariant Burnside groups in higher dimensions and modular symbols, a notion in the theory of curves.  


Apart from the intrinsic mathematical beauty of this subject, we are seeing increasingly important applications in information technology, cryptography, and data analysis. In turn, some of the numerical experiments accomplished under grant would not have been possible without fast computers and strong computational packages, such as Magma. 


The PI presented the results of this work at 31 international conferences worldwide, in addition to 24 colloquia and seminar talks.
